title: Lesson 56 - More on Who; Sino, Kanino & Nakanino

contents.markdown: We introduced _sino_ in one of the first lessons and promised to get deeper, so here we are. _Sino_ is the ang form of “who”. In this lesson we cover sino deeper, and introduce the _ng, sa_ and _nasa_ forms as well.
<u>Sino</u>
In general, _sino_ is an alternate for _alin_ that only works with people. We will always use _sino_ when working with people in this book. Here are four common ways that _sino_ is used.
sinong + person (Tag.) = which person (Eng.)

item.tagalog: Sinong estudyante ang nag-aral ng Ingles?

contents.markdown: sino + person (Tag.) = who is person (Eng.)
**Note: Person takes _ang_ form.**

item.tagalog: Sino ang estudyanteng nag-aral ng Ingles?
item.english: Who is the student who studied English?

contents.markdown: sino + people (Tag.) = which of the people (Eng.)
**Note: People takes _sa_ form.**

item.tagalog: Sino sa mga estudyanteng nag-aral ng Ingles?
item.english: Which of the students who studied English?

contents.markdown: \*\*Sino\*\*+ ang + phrase? (Tag) = Who phrase? (Eng)
Similarly:

item.tagalog: Sinong bata ang kumakain ng lechon?
Sinong estudyante ang nag-aral ng Ingles?

contents.markdown: <u>Kanino</u>
_Kanino_ is the _sa_ form of _sino_, and it can take the place of _sa_ form pronouns and people. _Kanino_ phrases are normally near the front of the sentence. Take the sentence:

item.tagalog: Nagbigay si Maria ng tsokolate kay David.

contents.markdown: Replacing _kay David_ with _kanino_ and moving it to the front:

item.tagalog: Kanino nagbigay si Maria ng tsokolate?
item.english: Who did Maria give chocolate to?

item.tagalog: Para kanino gumagawa si Joe ng lechon?
item.english: Who is Joe making lechon for?
Who did you tell the truth to?

contents.markdown: Kanino can also be used for possessives:
\*\*kanino\*\*+ linker + phrase (Tag.) = whose phrase (Eng.)

item.tagalog: Kaninong estudyante ang nag-aral ng Ingles?

contents.markdown: <u>Nakanino</u>
_Nakanino_ is the _nasa_ form of _sino_, and it can take the place of _na kay_ or _na kina_ noun clauses. Take the sentence:
Replacing _Na kina Joshua_ with _Nakanino_:
_Nakanino_ above means “at whose place” but it can also mean “who has”:

item.english: Who has the food?/Whose place is the food at?
Whose place are Joe and Angel at?
Who has the cat?/Who is the cat with?

contents.markdown: <u>Extra: Nino</u>
_Nino_ is the _ng_ form of _sino_, and it can take the place of _ng_ form personal pronouns and people. It is normally used in possessive phrases. Take the sentence:
Replacing _ko_ with _nino_:
However, it is more common to use the _kanino_+ linker structure covered above.
It is also possible to replace _ng_ form actors in clauses with _nino_:
But it is much more common to use _sino ang_ to express these:
We will not use _nino_ from now on.

exampleSentences.tagalog: Kaninong pangulo ang ganito? Kasing nakakainis ba siya ni Diego?
exampleSentences.english: Whose president is like this? Is he as annoying as Diego?

exampleSentences.tagalog: Nakanino sina Luis at Diego? Wala sila sa bahay.
exampleSentences.english: Whose place are Luis and Diego at? They are not at home.

exampleSentences.tagalog: Sino sa mga pinagtawanan ang parang asawa mo?
exampleSentences.english: Which of the ones who were mocked is like your wife?

exampleSentences.tagalog: Para kanino kumuha si Mrs. Castillo ng trabahong ito?
exampleSentences.english: Who did Mrs. Castillo get this job for?

exampleSentences.tagalog: Sinong babae ang mas maganda kaysa kay Jessica?
exampleSentences.english: Which woman is more beautiful than Jessica?

exampleSentences.tagalog: Hindi ko alam kung nakanino ang sobrang pagod na bata.
exampleSentences.english: I do not know who the very tired child is with.

exampleSentences.tagalog: Sino sa mga estudyante ang pinakatakot?
exampleSentences.english: Which of the students is the most frightened?

exampleSentences.tagalog: Kaninong guro ang pinag-usapan natin nang ganun?
exampleSentences.english: Whose teacher did we discuss like that?

exampleSentences.tagalog: Hindi pareho sina Analyn at Jasmine. Nakanino sila?
exampleSentences.english: Analyn and Jasmine are not the same. Whose place are they at?
